title: Psychosocial and medication interventions to stop or reduce alcohol consumption during pregnancy
authors: Minozzi, S; Ambrosi, L; Saulle, R; Uhm, SS; Terplan, M; Sinclair, JMA; Agabio, R

response.output:
Are talking therapies and medicines effective for helping pregnant women stop or reduce drinking alcohol?

Key messages

– Brief talking therapies may help more pregnant women to stop drinking alcohol completely compared to usual care. We found no studies that looked at using medicines for this purpose.

– Talking therapies probably make little to no difference to the number of women who stay in treatment. We do not know if these therapies help women reduce the amount they drink if they do not stop completely, because the evidence is very uncertain. None of the studies reported on any unwanted effects.

– More research is needed to be more certain about the effects of talking therapies. Future studies should also look at the safety and benefits of medicines for pregnant women who drink alcohol, especially for those who drink heavily.

What is the problem with drinking alcohol during pregnancy?

Drinking alcohol during pregnancy can be harmful to an unborn baby and can cause lifelong problems. Despite these known harms, about 1 in 10 pregnant women worldwide drink alcohol. In Europe, this number is higher, at around 1 in 4. It is important to find effective ways to help pregnant women stop or reduce their drinking.

What treatments can help pregnant women stop drinking?

There are two main types of treatment that could help.
– Talking therapies (also called psychosocial interventions) include things like counseling, support sessions, and motivational advice from a healthcare worker.
– Medicines can also be used to help people with alcohol problems, but it is important to know if they are safe and effective to use during pregnancy.

What did we want to find out?

We wanted to find out if talking therapies or medicines help pregnant women to stop or reduce drinking alcohol. We also wanted to know if these treatments had any unwanted or harmful effects.

What did we do?

We searched for studies that compared talking therapies or medicines with usual care or no treatment for pregnant women who drink alcohol. We compared and summarized the results of these studies and rated our confidence in the evidence.

What did we find?

We found 8 studies that included 1369 pregnant women. All 8 studies looked at talking therapies. We did not find any studies that looked at using medicines.

The talking therapies were usually brief, involving one to five short sessions with a healthcare worker. Most studies took place in the USA. The women in the comparison groups received usual care, which included advice to stop drinking.

Main results

Compared with usual care, we found that:
– talking therapies may help more women to stop drinking alcohol completely.
– talking therapies probably make little to no difference to the number of women who stay in treatment until the end.
– we do not know if talking therapies help women to drink less alcohol if they do not stop completely. The evidence for this is very uncertain.
– none of the studies reported on unwanted effects, so we do not know if the talking therapies have any risks.

What are the limitations of the evidence?

We have little confidence in some of the evidence. This is because it is possible that people in the studies were aware of which treatment they were getting, which could have affected the results. Also, some of the studies were small.

How up to date is this evidence?

The evidence is up to date to January 2024.
